item.title: Sri Lanka Declares ‘Largest’ Disaster as Cyclone Death Toll Rises to 355
item.description: The country’s president said the nationwide flooding after the storm hit last week was the most challenging natural disaster in the island nation’s history.
item.dc:creator: Pamodi Waravita and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: A man is carried through flooded streets on the outskirts of Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Sunday.

item.title: Outdoor Concerts? Uncovered Hair? Shimmying in Public? Is This Iran?
item.description: Young people across Iran have been leading a dramatic change in social mores in recent months. “We have a fearless young generation that is breaking taboos.”
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Sanam Mahoozi

item.title: Netanyahu’s Pardon Request Borrows From Trump’s Playbook
item.description: In many ways, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s request mimics how President Trump has assailed his perceived enemies and attacked legal proceedings against him.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel. His petition to the country’s president, Isaac Herzog, admitted nothing and expressed no contrition.

item.title: Hong Kong Contractors Used Unsafe Netting at Fire Site, Officials Say
item.description: Investigators say contractors wrapped the buildings in substandard scaffolding netting and then sought to hide it from inspectors. The toll from the fire rose to 151.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Joy Dong and Selam Gebrekidan
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Green netting and bamboo scaffolding are visible on buildings at Wang Fuk Court, the Hong Kong apartment complex engulfed by fire last week.

item.title: What Jamaica Wants After Deadly Hurricane? Visit Us, Island Says.
item.description: Tourism accounts for nearly a third of Jamaica’s economy, so officials are rushing to reopen dozens of hotels in time to salvage the vital winter travel season.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles and Erin Schaff
item.media:description: Kellanie Kerr working by flashlight at a tourist shop this month in Negril, Jamaica.

item.title: Floods in Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Thailand and Vietnam Have Killed Over 1,200. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Unusually destructive storms have killed more than 1,200 people across the region and displaced millions in South and Southeast Asia.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg, Muktita Suhartono and Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:description: A village affected by a flash flood in Batang Toru, North Sumatra, Indonesia, on Monday.

item.title: Zelensky Turns to Europe After Talks With U.S. Officials
item.description: Ukraine’s president met with President Emmanuel Macron of France on Monday as Steve Witkoff, President Trump’s special envoy, was traveling to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and President Emmanuel Macron of France met in Paris on Monday as part of a flurry of diplomatic talks to end the war with Russia.

item.title: India Is a Rising Power, but Breathing in Its Capital Is Hazardous
item.description: With little being done to clean the skies over New Delhi, the huge city struggles with toxic air.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Pragati K.B., Hari Kumar and Anindito Mukherjee
item.media:description: A jogger near India Gate, the national war memorial in New Delhi, shrouded in haze caused by air pollution.

item.title: Pope Leo Calls for a Two-State Solution in Mideast Conflict
item.description: The pope, arriving in Lebanon, also encouraged that country’s Christians to stay where they are, despite economic, political and security concerns.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Leo XIV arriving in Beirut, Lebanon, on Sunday.

item.title: Fed Up With the Taliban, Pakistan Expels Masses of Afghans
item.description: Labeling Afghans a national security threat, Pakistan has forced out about a million this year, depriving them of a haven from Afghanistan’s turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier, Zia ur-Rehman and Asim Hafeez
item.media:credit: Asim Hafeez for The New York Times

item.title: Hong Kong’s Migrant Domestic Workers Mourn Their Losses in Deadly Fire
item.description: At least eight workers died, and many of those who survived, after saving children and others in their care, are worried about losing their jobs and being forced to leave.
item.dc:creator: Anjali Tsui and Francesca Regalado
item.media:description: Filipinos taking part in a community prayer service on Sunday in Hong Kong for the victims of the Nov. 26 fire in the Tai Po district of the city.

item.title: Deadly Floods in Indonesia Leave Hundreds Missing
item.description: Hundreds of people have been killed and millions displaced as extreme weather has ravaged Southeast Asia this month. Indonesia’s heavy rain was linked to two tropical cyclones.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: A flood-damaged district in the Indonesian province of Aceh on Sunday.

item.title: Lebanon’s Christians Look to Pope Leo’s Visit for a Message of Hope and Peace
item.description: The pontiff met political leaders upon his arrival on Sunday and will later say Mass at a Beirut port destroyed by an explosion five years ago.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Leo XIV was greeted by President Joseph Aoun of Lebanon and Nehmat Aoun, the first lady, upon arrival in Beirut on Sunday.

item.title: Trump-Endorsed Candidate and Sportscaster Lead Honduran Presidential Race
item.description: Electoral authorities said partial results showed the two conservative candidates were virtually tied — and far ahead of the governing left-wing party.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal and Jeff Ernst
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump endorsed Nasry Asfura, one of the right-wing candidates for the Honduran presidency.

item.title: Putin to Meet With Trump’s Envoy as U.S. Pushes for Ukraine Deal
item.description: In Moscow, Steve Witkoff, President Trump’s special envoy, is expected to present President Vladimir V. Putin with a revised proposal to end the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Steve Witkoff, President Trump’s special envoy, speaking to reporters outside the White House in February. He is scheduled to be in Moscow on Tuesday.

item.title: Right to Jury Trial in England and Wales to Be Restricted in Some Cases
item.description: The British justice secretary, David Lammy, is set to announce the contentious move as part of a broader overhaul of the criminal justice system, amid a yearslong backlog.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: David Lammy, the justice secretary and deputy prime minister, planned significant changes to the criminal justice system, citing a “courts emergency that has left victims of the most serious crimes waiting years for justice.”

item.title: Son of El Chapo Pleads Guilty to Kidnapping Father’s Former Cartel Partner
item.description: Joaquín Guzmán López admitted to having the once-untouchable drug kingpin Ismael Zambada García abducted and flown to the United States, among a sweeping set of other crimes.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Robert Chiarito
item.media:description: A plane believed to have been used to kidnap the drug kingpin Ismael Zambada García in Santa Teresa, N.M., last year.

item.title: An Anti-Polarization Pope
item.description: What Pope Leo’s first international trip tells us about the leader of the Catholic Church.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Leo at the Blue Mosque in Istanbul on Saturday.

item.title: Trump Becomes the Wild Card in Razor-Thin Honduras Election
item.description: President Trump warned that if his favored candidate didn’t win, the United States would “not be throwing good money after bad” at the country.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: A campaign poster for Nasry Asfura, the right-wing candidate backed by President Trump, last month on a street in Tegucigalpa, Honduras.

item.title: Why Is Budapest, the ‘City of Baths,’ Running Out of Bathhouses?
item.description: In Budapest, political disputes and aging infrastructure have led to cascading problems, and prolonged closings, at several of the city’s beloved baths.
item.dc:creator: Tas Tóbiás
item.media:description: Two of the Art Nouveau pools at Gellért Bath.

item.title: College Student Is Deported During Trip Home for Thanksgiving
item.description: Any Lucia López Belloza, 19, was detained by immigration agents at the Boston airport before a flight to surprise her family in Texas for Thanksgiving. She is now in Honduras.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch and Annie Correal
item.media:description: Any Lucia Lopez Belloza celebrating her high school graduation in Texas.

item.title: ‘Imperial Israel’ in the New Middle East
item.description: A series of attacks show how Israel has expanded its reach in the region.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: After an Israeli drone strike in Lebanon in September.

item.title: Netanyahu Asks Israel’s President to Pardon Him in Corruption Cases
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu made the contentious appeal weeks after President Trump had made the same request to the Israeli president.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel speaking in November at the Knesset in Jerusalem.

item.title: The Ex-President Whom Trump Plans to Pardon Flooded America With Cocaine
item.description: Juan Orlando Hernández, whom Mr. Trump called a victim of persecution, helped orchestrate a decades-long trafficking conspiracy. It ravaged his Central American country.
item.dc:creator: Santul Nerkar, Annie Correal and Colin Moynihan
item.media:description: When Juan Orlando Hernández was extradited to the United States, his own country erupted in celebration.

item.title: Top Trump Aides to Meet With Ukrainians in Florida on Sunday
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio, Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner plan to discuss peace terms again after an uproar over a 28-point proposal drafted with Russian input.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio will attend talks with Ukrainian officials in Florida on Sunday.

item.title: Gazans Say Israeli Forces Killed Two Children, Amid Persistent Violence
item.description: The Israeli military said it had fired on two “suspects” on Saturday who had crossed cease-fire lines in southern Gaza and did not comment on reports that they were young children.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Rawan Sheikh Ahmad
item.media:description: Displaced Palestinians standing by a fire beside their tent in Gaza City on Friday.

item.title: Mourners Honor Victims of Hong Kong Apartment Fire
item.description: The police said they expected the death toll of 128 to rise as the authorities began combing through the charred apartment towers.
item.dc:creator: Anjali Tsui
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: People affected by the fire at a shelter on Friday.

item.title: Did Pope Leo Pray in Istanbul’s Blue Mosque? Not Visibly, at Least.
item.description: Leo XIV is being closely watched on an inaugural trip to Turkey and Lebanon to spread a message of peace and outreach.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Leo XIV visiting the Sultan Ahmed Mosque in Istanbul on Saturday.

item.title: Highlight Reel
item.description: As the year comes to a close, we want to know your highly specific, idiosyncratic bests of 2025.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Fresh Reporting on Asylum Seekers at the U.S.-Canadian Border
item.description: Canada has made its border with the United States tougher to cross. Here’s what we learned through monthlong reporting on a single case.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.category: Book of Lives: A Memoir of Sorts (Book)
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rahel Negassi at her new home in Kitchener, Ontario. She has applied for her Ontario nurse permit, and she hopes to be able to work soon.

item.title: In Firing His No. 2, Zelensky Loses Both a Negotiator and an Enforcer
item.description: Andriy Yermak had ensured internal discipline in Ukraine’s wartime politics. He also led the country’s peace negotiations, which now must go on without him.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier in the eastern Donbas region. Andriy Yermak, President Volodymyr Zelensky’s former chief of staff, had negotiated to soften a peace proposal that included withdrawing from territory in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Latin American Leaders Face Both Trump and Voters Deported by the U.S.
item.description: The upcoming election in Honduras shows how politicians must balance cooperation with the Trump administration with their obligation to undocumented citizens in the United States who may be deported.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delmar Méndez, 53, his partner and their 3-year-old son were deported from the United States in February after their asylum claim was denied, they said.

item.title: Israeli Hostage Recounts Beatings and Starvation During Hamas Captivity
item.description: Segev Kalfon said he endured physical abuse and mind games during 738 days in the hands of Hamas. Now, he asks why it took so long for Israel to bring him home.
item.dc:creator: Natan Odenheimer, Isabel Kershner and Avishag Shaar-Yashuv
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Segev Kalfon in Ramat Gan, this month.

item.title: The Ukrainians Stuck in Russia’s New Gulag
item.description: Even if a peace can be reached, it won’t be easy to solve the problem of Ukrainian civilians languishing in Russian jails. This is one prisoner’s story.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
International Committee of the Red Cross
Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mykola Zakhozhyi and his wife, Iryna. “The uncertainty was killing me,” Ms. Zakhozha said. “I neither slept nor ate. I bended away from my children, friends, everyone.”

item.title: Syria Tiptoes Toward Transitional Justice One Year After Assad’s Ouster
item.description: Fourteen people are on trial, charged with crimes related to an outbreak of sectarian violence under the new government. The abuses of the old Assad regime still await a reckoning.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Saad Alnassife
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The matter is now in the government’s hands,” said Jomaa Aldbis Alanzi, one of Syria’s leading judges.

item.title: Russia Bombards Ukraine for Nearly 10 Hours in a Deadly Assault
item.description: The attack came as U.S. officials were expected to hold peace talks with Ukrainian and Russian officials in the coming days.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Oleksandr Chubko
item.media:description: A damaged residential building following an air attack in Kyiv on Saturday.

item.title: As Cyclone Deaths Pass 150, Sri Lanka Is Overwhelmed by Rescue Demand
item.description: Rescue efforts across the nation of 23 million have been hampered by disruptions in transport and telecommunications.
item.dc:creator: Pamodi Waravita and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: People wading through a flooded street in Colombo, the capital of Sri Lanka, on Saturday.

item.title: Deadly Hong Kong Fire Is a Test of Beijing’s Rule in the City
item.description: After Beijing reshaped the political order in Hong Kong in its image, the fire has become a test of how well that new system can govern in a crisis.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue and retrieval workers at the Wang Fuk Court towers in Hong Kong, on Friday.

item.title: South Africans Were Promised Job, but Ended Up ‘Going to War’ for Russia
item.description: The South African government is investigating how more than a dozen men unwittingly ended up on the front line in Russia’s war on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Zimasa Matiwane
item.category: Spear of the Nation (MK) (South African Political Party)
item.media:description: Smoke rising after shelling in the eastern Donetsk region of Ukraine in 2024.

item.title: Where Hundreds of Undocumented Migrants Have Died in Custody
item.description: Malaysia launched a “year of enforcement” in response to a surge in undocumented migrants, many of them from Myanmar. Some faced nightmarish fates.
item.dc:creator: Zunaira Saieed and Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A migrant detention center in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, in 2023.

item.title: Trump to Pardon Juan Orlando Hernández, Honduran Ex-Leader Convicted in Drug Case
item.description: Juan Orlando Hernández was accused of receiving millions in bribes and partnering with cocaine traffickers. He was convicted in Manhattan in 2024 and sentenced to 45 years in prison.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal, Jeff Ernst, Shawn McCreesh and David C. Adams
item.media:description: Juan Orlando Hernández, then the president of Honduras, speaking at the United Nations in 2019. President Trump announced Friday he would pardon him.

item.title: Trump Spoke by Phone Last Week With Maduro, Venezuela’s Leader
item.description: They discussed a possible meeting between the two of them, but nothing has been scheduled, and the administration continues to increase the military pressure on Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicolás Maduro, the president of Venezuela, faces intensifying pressure military and diplomatic pressure from the United States.

item.title: Parts of Southern Ontario Pummeled by Snow Squalls and Heavy Winds
item.description: More localized bands of squalls were expected to form, with up to two feet of snow possible in some areas, according to Canada’s forecast agency.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: Officials in Ontario warned of possible road closures and urged that nonessential travel and outdoor activities be avoided.

item.title: Andriy Yermak Resigns: What to Know About Ukrainian Official
item.description: The chief of staff to President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine was seen as the second-most powerful person in Ukraine. He was dismissed on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Oscar Del Pozo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Andriy Yermak, the chief of staff to President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, resigned on Friday amid a corruption scandal.

item.title: Rebel Nuns Can Live in Old Abbey, if They Give Up Social Media
item.description: After the octogenarian nuns refused to return to their senior center, the abbot has finally folded. But he has some conditions.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Roderick Aichinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Sister Bernadette, Sister Rita and Sister Regina. Their lawyer said he had advised them to decline the abbot’s terms.

item.title: Trump’s Response to Shooting Shows Intensified Anti-Migrant Stance
item.description: The president is furiously demanding limits on migration and attacking ethnic groups as he steps up his efforts to equate immigration with crime and economic distress.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.category: US Federal Takeover of Metropolitan Police Dept (DC)
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: The shooting of two National Guard members and President Trump’s response insures that immigration will remain at the center of American politics heading into the 2026 midterm election cycle.

item.title: A Hong Kong Fire Survivor’s Escape, in His Own Words
item.description: In his own words, William Li, a resident of the Hong Kong apartment complex that became an inferno, recounted how he and two neighbors survived until help arrived.
item.dc:creator: Anjali Tsui
item.media:description: William Li photographed the burning Wang Fuk Court complex after escaping from the fire.

item.title: Officials Had Been Warned for Over a Year Before Hong Kong Fire
item.description: Residents of Wang Fuk Court apartments had raised concerns about flammable foam panels and scaffold netting, but the government did not take decisive action.
item.dc:creator: Selam Gebrekidan, Amy Chang Chien and Joy Dong
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times

item.title: Andriy Yermak, Zelensky’s Chief of Staff, Resigns
item.description: Andriy Yermak, President Volodymyr Zelensky’s chief of staff and top peace negotiator, became the highest-ranking casualty of an investigation into a vast kickback scheme.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker and Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: Servant of the People (Ukrainian Political Party)
item.media:description: Andriy Yermak, in Washington last year. He had been widely seen as the country’s second most powerful person.

item.title: Israeli Raid in Southern Syria Kills at Least 13, Syrian Officials Say
item.description: The raid was one of Israel’s deadliest cross-border incursions since Bashar al-Assad, Syria’s former dictator, was ousted last year.
item.dc:creator: Reham Mourshed and Euan Ward
item.media:description: Damage in Beit Jinn, a town in southern Syria, after an Israeli raid on Friday.

item.title: Israeli Forces Kill Two Palestinians in West Bank After They Appear to Surrender, Video Shows
item.description: The Israeli authorities said they were investigating the shooting, which came amid days of extensive military operations in the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Sanjana Varghese and Fatima AbdulKarim
item.media:description: A still from Palestine TV of two Palestinian men kneeling on the ground shortly before they were shot dead during an Israeli military operation in the West Bank city of Jenin on Thursday.

item.title: Worker Cleared of Stealing Snacks From Office Fridge After 2 Years in Court
item.description: A South Korean man accused of stealing a Choco Pie and a mini custard cake was acquitted after a prosecution that drew widespread criticism.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Boxes of Choco Pies on a shelf of a convenience store in Seoul, in October.

item.title: Aftershocks of an Art Crime Reverberate in Japan
item.description: At least four works by a famous convicted forger have been discovered in Japan. Transparency about the mistakes, however, has sparked as much curiosity as scandal.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni

item.title: Hondurans Fear Unrest Ahead of Election as Trump Endorses a Candidate
item.description: On Sunday, voters will choose between a left-wing presidential candidate and two conservatives, one backed by President Trump. The results are likely to be bitterly contested.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal, Jeff Ernst and Daniele Volpe
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times

item.title: Home of Ukraine’s Lead Negotiator Is Searched in Corruption Case
item.description: The scrutiny of Andriy Yermak, President Volodymyr Zelensky’s chief of staff, could disrupt U.S.-led peace talks and further rattle Ukrainian politics.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Andriy Yermak, Ukraine’s chief negotiator, speaking in Geneva in November. He had been widely seen as the country’s second most powerful person.
